newsitem.title: USA: Chrysler to make 180,000 flexible fuel minivans.
newsitem.headline: Chrysler to make 180,000 flexible fuel minivans.

text.p: Chrysler Corp. said Tuesday it would make 180,000 minivans that can run on either gasoline or ethanol, the second major automaker in a week to unveil a large-scale alternative fuel vehicle programme.
The vehicles will be available starting in the 1998 model year, which begins this autumn, a Chrysler official said at the Governors' Ethanol Coalition Conference.

Ford Motor Co. said last week it plans to produce 250,000 flexible-fuel pickup trucks, sedans and minivans starting in the 1998 for the 1999 model year. Ford plans to spend about $300 per vehicle so they can run on gasoline or a mixture of gasoline and ethanol, alcohol made from corn and grains that burns cleaner than gasoline but is less fuel-efficient.
General Motors Corp., the world's largest automaker, offers a limited number of alternative fuel vehicles but has not announced a large-scale production programme.

The Chrysler official would not comment on how much it will cost the nation's third largest automaker to adapt the flexible-fuel technology, but he said it will not affect the retail price of the minivans.

Chrysler said flexible-fuel minivans that run on E85 -- a combination of 85 percent ethanol and 15 percent gasoline -- will get about 33 percent fewer miles per gallon than minivans that run on gasoline.
All of Chrysler's 1998 Plymouth Voyager, Dodge Caravan and Chrysler Town and Country minivans that come with the standard 3.3-litre, six-cylinder engine will be able to run on either fuel.

The metallic blue minivan unveiled Tuesday looked similar to other Chrysler vans, except that it had the word "Ethanol" emblazoned on its side. The logo will not appear on vehicles sold to the public, officials said.
Bill Rotramel, a Chrysler spokesman at the unveiling, said that in addition to helping the enivronment, flexible-fuel vehicles helped lower U.S. dependence on oil imports.
Chrysler will manufacture the vehicles at its assembly plants in Windsor, Ontario, and in Fenton, Mo.
Members of the National Corn Growers Association and officials from corn-growing states welcomed Chrysler's move.

"If 250,000 of these vehicles used as little as 100 gallons each year of E85, that would produce a market for 25 million gallons of ethanol or about 10 million bushels of corn," NCGA Vice President Ryland Utlaut said.

Chrysler officials said little about the federal fuel credits automakers receive for offering flexible-fuel vehicles. Such credits allow automakers to raise their corporate average fuel economy, or CAFE. That, in turn, allows them to sell more of the highly profitable -- but less fuel-efficient -- pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles.
The federal government sets CAFE limits to force automakers to offer a certain number of fuel-efficient vehicles.
Rotramel said Chrysler will benefit from the credits obtained from the ethanol programme, but he declined to give the number of CAFE credits Chrysler will get for each one sold.
At present only about 40 gas stations across the country offer E85 to the public, but an ethanol industry official said more stations would be added this year and next.
Chrysler stock added 12.5 cents to $33 in consolidated trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
